comments: A large and very alkaline shallow lake, it is a designated RAMSAR site. It is significant for migratory birds and a federally recognized Bird Sanctuary. Water levels were very low recently due to drought. In 2005, the lake dried up completely.

comments: No other information on this lake.

comments: Part of Prefontaine Brock Lakes Natural Area.

title: Bruce Lake
comments: No other information on this lake.

comments: Considered a large shallow lake but water levels are not considered a problem here.

title: Buffalo Lake
management_agency: Alberta Parks; Alberta Environment; Buffalo Lake Management Team
comments: There are a couple of Buffalo Lakes in Alberta, this is the one near Mirror and White Sands. Considered a shallow lake where water is managed to be within a certain range of water level.

management_agency: Alberta Environment; Alberta Parks; Alberta Government
comments: Important site for waterfowl.

comments: Clearwater oil sands located at the lake and in surrounding region. The lake is large and considered unproductive for fish. Part of the lake is in Saskatchewan.

comments: Considered a large shallow lake.

comments: No other information on this lake.

title: Deadhorse Lake
comments: No other information on this lake.

title: Dinosaur Provincial Lake
comments: Cannot locate the lake of the Dinosaur Provincial Park, coordinates from the source does not locate a lake, entered these coordinates for the Red Deer River adjacent to the park.

title: Driedmeat Lake
comments: Very shallow and highly eutrophic. Located where the Battle River widens.

title: Eagle Lake
comments: There are a couple of Eagle Lakes in Alberta. Assuming this is the one associated with Namaka Lake and Stobart Lake. Eagle Lake is the largest of this complex of lakes. Most of the shoreline vegetation has been grazed by cattle. These lakes are globally significant for migrating waterbirds.

title: Ethel Lake
comments: Water was drawn by Esso Resources Canada since 1965 for an oil sands pilot plant. Close to the larger Cold Lake.

title: Etzikom Coulee
comments: No other information on this lake. Inflows to Paklowki Lake Bird Sanctuary, an ephemeral lake.

title: Fincastle Lake/Fincastle Reservoir
comments: No other information on this lake. Near Taber Lake.

title: Fork Lake
comments: No other information on this lake.

comments: No other information on this lake. Part of Fox Lake 162 Indian Reserve, Little Red River Cree Nation.

title: Frog Lake
region_associations: Eastern North Saskatchewan River Basin; Frog Lake First Nation; Puskiakiwenin Indian Reserve 122; Unipouheos Indian Reserve 121
comments: A very large and deep lake. Water level has slowly been declining.

title: Garner Lake
region_associations: Garner Lake Provincial Park; Beaver River Watershed; boreal forest region
comments: Managed for fisheries. Surrounding land is used for agriculture and grazing.

title: Genesee Lake
region_associations: Genesee Natural Area; North Saskatchewan River

title: Gleniffer Lake
region_associations: Glennifer Reservoir Provincial Recreation Area; Red Deer River
comments: Major drawdown to low levels makes it unlikely that emergent vegetation zone develops.

title: Gull Lake
comments: Was first used for hydroelectric generation but the dam was destroyed and then rebuilt in 1921 after complaints about low water levels. A large shallow lake, it is slightly saline.

title: Handhills Lake
comments: Shallow lake vulnerable to drought.

title: Harold Lake
comments: Not much information on this lake.

title: Hastings Lake
comments: A medium sized shallow lake, it is slightly saline and water level has been declining since 1997. It has a natural shoreline and many islands.

title: Horsefly Reservoir
comments: Small shallow reservoir connected to Taber Lake via canals.

title: Isle Lake
region_associations: Sturgeon River watershed; North Saskatchewan River Basin; Lac Ste. Anne; Wabamun Lake; Isle Lake Natural Area
comments: A shallow large lake. Water levels have been declining since the 1990s.

title: Lac La Biche/LLB Lake
management_agency: Sir Winston Churchill Provincial Park (islands), Alberta Environment
region_associations: Boreal Forest Natural Region of Alberta; Sir Winston Churchill Provincial Park
comments: Considered a major grebe breeding lake with a diversity of habitat. This boreal lake is composed of two large basins.

title: Lac La Nonne
region_associations: Athabasca River Watershed; Lac La Nonne Natural Area; Boreal Forest
comments: A large, deep, and developed lake busy with recreation, this lake was a trading post for the Hudson's Bay County in the early 1800s. It is managed for recreation and fisheries and lacks quality nesting site for waterfowl and waterbirds.

title: Lac Sante
comments: Composed of four basins, largely developed for agricultural purposes.

title: Lac Ste. Anne
region_associations:
Isle Lake; Sturgeon River watershed; North Saskatchewan
 River Basin
comments: A shallow lake, water level had been declining since the 1990s. The water was believed to have healing powers so there were religious pilgrimages to the lake.

title: Lake Newell and Kitsim Reservoir
comments: One of the largest reservoirs of Alberta, it has large annual water fluctuations and low aquatic vegetation density. Lake Newell and Kitsim Reservoir are associated together as Kitsim Reservoir does not turn up anything. Kitsim is smaller and to the west of Lake Newell. Coordinates are for Lake Newell. The sites are used for livestock and water supply and is situated on a gas field.

title: Landry Lake
comments: Not much information on this lake.

title: Lesser Slave Lake
management_agency: Alberta Environment; Alberta Parks; Lesser Slave Lake Wildlands Provincial Park
region_associations: Boreal Forest; Lesser Slave Provincial Parks; Lesser Slave River Basin
comments: Second largest lake within Alberta, it has a diversity of habitat and is important for birds. A bird observatory is situated on its shore.

title: Little Fish Lake
comments: A shallow slightly alkaline lake.

title: Louisiana Lakes Reservoir
comments: Not much information on this group of lakes.

title: Manatokan Lake
comments: Not much information on this lake.

title: Marguerite Lake
comments: Not much information on this lake. A very peaty lake of oil sands. Fire-flooding tests were conducted at this lake in the early 1980s.

title: McGregor Lake/Lake McGregor
comments: Supplies water for irrigation and other uses via canals and other reservoirs.

title: Ministik Lake
management_agency: Edmonton and Area Land Trust; Alberta Environment
comments: A saline lake with an alkaline shore, it supports a diversity of upland and wetland habitat. It site atop an oil field and there is a lot of oil and gas extraction activity as well as recreation.

title: Miquelon Lake
comments: Shallow and salty, this is the largest of 3 Miquelon Lakes that remained from a larger lake.

title: Missawawi Lake
region_associations: Kinosiu Lake; Lac La Biche Basin; Beaver River Watershed
comments: Drainage connection with Kinosiu Lake.

title: Moose Lake
region_associations: Moose Lake Provincial Park, Moose Lake Watershed, Muriel Lake
comments: A very busy lake with recreationists and residents, it has ongoing issues with harmful algal blooms.

title: Muriel Lake
region_associations: Moose Lake, Muriel Lake Basin, Muriel Lake Provincial Recreation Area
comments: Large and shallow, this lake is managed for fisheries and has a rocky shore for most of the shoreline. There is a large population of colonial nesting waterbirds but there is also a lot of development around this lake. This lake lost a lot of volume since the 1970s and water levels dropped drastically.

title: Murray Lake
comments: Not much information on this lake.

title: Namaka Lake
comments: Network of lakes with Eagle and Stobart lakes and is a globally significant for migrating waterbirds. Over a thousand Western grebes stopover here during migration. Nesting of grebes have also been observed in this complex.

title: North Buck Lake
region_associations: North Buck Lake Provincial Recreation Area
comments: A popular recreation lake, it is managed for fisheries.

title: Oakland Lake
comments: Not much information on this lake.

title: Pakowki Lake
comments: Supports large congregations of migrating birds and provides important bird habitat such as marshes and open water. Considered an intermittent ephemeral lake that has dried out in previous years. The area is significant to the oil and gas industry. Hundreds of thousands of waterfowl died from avian botulism in 1995.

title: Peace River
comments: Portion of the river between La Crete and Fort Vermilion according to the coordinates in the record.

title: Pigeon Lake (Woodpecker Lake)
region_associations: Battle River Watershed, Pigeon Lake Provincial Park
comments: This large shallow lake has fluctuating fish populations and a very developed shoreline. It is one Alberta's largest and most popular lakes.

title: Pine Lake
management_agency: Alberta Environment; Pine Lake Restoration Society
comments: A small and very developed lake that had declining water quality.

title: Rattlesnake Lake/Sauder's Reservoir
management_agency: South East Alberta Watershed Alliance (SEAWA); Saint Mary River Irrigation District (SMRID)
comments: Experiences strong winds and water level fluctuations as water is used for irrigation.

title: Reita Lake
comments: Not much information on this lake. Various oil sands projects in this region.

title: Sandy Lake
comments: There are many Stony Lakes in Alberta. This is the one near Calahoo in the Stony Point Study Area. It is shallow and highly developed. Water levels were declining in the early 1990s.

title: Saskatoon Lake
region_associations: Boreal Parkland ecoregion; Saskatoon Lake Bird Sanctuary; Saskatoon Island Provincial Park
comments: A very shallow, medium-sized, and slightly saline lake.

title: Scope Reservoir/Scope Lake/Hays Lake/Hays Reservoir
comments: Minimal marsh area but is surrounded by native grassland .

title: Seven Persons Lake
comments: Within the SEAWA Seven Persons Creek watershed.

title: Shanks Lake
comments: Not much information on this lake. This lake was considered for improvements to increase water storage capacity but it is limited in size and has major water quality issues, especially with salinity.

title: Shooting Lake
comments: Not much information on this lake.

title: Skeleton Lake
region_associations: Town of Boyle; Beaver River Basin
comments: A highly developed lake, it is used for drinking water for the Town of Boyle and for recreation. It is a popular fishing lake. This lake had very low water levels in the 1990s and continues to face water level declines.

title: Stobart Lake
management_agency: Alberta Conservation Association; Alberta Environment and Parks; Ducks Unlimited Canada
comments: Network of lakes with Eagle and Namaka lakes and is a globally significant for migrating waterbirds. Stobart Lake is considered the most natural of the three lakes with extensive marsh habitat. Over a thousand Western grebes stopover this complex of lakes during migration. Nesting of grebes have also been observed in this complex.

title: Suncor Base Plant
comments: Used approximate coordinates from the record. This is on the oil sands mining company's grounds. There are a few waterbodies on the property.

title: Sylvan Lake
comments: Water levels considered relatively stable.

title: Taber Lake
comments: Not much information on this lake. Near Fincastle Lake. Connected to Horsefly Lake Reservoir via canals

title: Thunder Lake
comments: This medium-sized lake has relatively stable water levels and is popular for sport fishing.

title: Tilley A Reservoir
comments: Part of the Tilley Slough area, a complex of sloughs, reservoirs, and lakes. Artificial islands were built to enhance waterfowl nesting.

title: Tilley B Reservoir
comments: Part of the Tilley Slough area, a complex of sloughs, reservoirs, and lakes. A solar power production plant was proposed near Tilley 'B' Reservoir. Artificial islands were built to enhance waterfowl nesting.

management_agency: Alberta Environment; Alberta Conservation Association; St. Mary River Irrigation District, County of Warner

title: Upper Therien Lake

comments: Small pothole lake.

title: Wabamun Lake
comments: There are many CO2 emitters, such as coal-fired plants, in the Wabamun region.

title: Watt Lake
comments: Not much information on this lake.

title: Whitefish Lake
comments: Not much information on this lake. Part of the Whitefish Lake First Nation.

title: Winagami Lake
comments: A large shallow lake with relatively stable water levels and a popular sport fishing spot.

title: Wolf Lake
comments: This deep lake hosts a diversity of wildlife habitat and is also popular for sport fishing.

title: Alamo Lake
management_agency: Arizona State Parks, US Army Corps of Engineers

title: Becker Lake
comments: Considered one of the oldest reservoirs in the White Mountain region.

comments: 6100 acres of Havasu Lake National Wildlife Refuge was carved out as Bill Williams NWR in 1993.

title: Cibola National Wildlife Refuge

Imperial NWR includes various lakes and wetlands along the Colorado River so the refuge as a whole is entered seperately from Imperial Reservoir and Martinez Lake.

title: Duck Lake, Creston Valley WMA (CVWMA)
primary_veg_for_nesting: Typha; Myriophylum| Cattail| reed canary grass; bulrush

comments: Unnamed lake, coordinates are for the closest lake just outside of Fernie.

title: Kamloops Lake
comments: Weyerhauser Pulp Mill discharged effluent upstream of the lake, causing the lake to have major water quality issues om the early 1970s. Water quality has since improved due to better treatment of the effluent.

region_associations: Duck Lake; Kootenay River; Kootenay Lake; Creston Valley WMA (CVWMA)
comments: Not much information on this lake.

title: Okanagan Lake

title: Sanctuary Lake
comments: Not much information on this lake.

title: Shuswap Lake
primary_veg_for_nesting: pond weed; sticks; emergent logs; cattail; reed canary grass; bulrush
management_agency: Province of British Columbia; Fraser Basin Council; SABNES (Ministry of Environment, Lands and Parks, Department of Fisheries and Oceans, Canadian Wildlife Service, Ducks Unlimited)
comments: Shuswap Lake is shaped like an H with four arms. Salmon Arm is the southwest arm, is the most reported on for grebes, and considered the most productive due to agricultural runoff..  The two south arms are for recreational use and the other two arms are undeveloped. This lake is considered a salmon nursery for sockeye salmon.

title: Summerland, unnamed lake nearby
comments: Coordinates are for an unnamed lake near Summerland.

primary_veg_for_nesting: Scirpus; Typha; Ranunculus; Leinna; Spirogyra; round-stem bulrush (Scirpus acutus)

comments: There are a few Swan Lakes in British Columbia. This one is near Okanagan Lake and Vernon. Not much information on this lake.

region_associations: Vancouver; Fraser River; George C. Reifel Migratory Bird Sanctuary
comments: At mouth of Fraser River and Strait of Georgia.

title: White Lake
comments: Small alkaline lake with structural water control.

title: Williams Lake
primary_veg_for_nesting: Myriophyllum| Cattail| round-stem bulrush (Scirpus acutus)| Scirpus
management_agency: Indian Reserve No. 1 (Sugar Cane Reserve); local First Nations band
comments: Not much information about this lake.

title: Antelope Lake
management_agency: U.S. Forest Service; California Department of Fish and Wildlife
region_associations: Plumas National Forest; Antelope Lake Recreation Area; Upper River Feather Lakes
comments: The smallest of three lakes of the Upper Feathers River Lakes. The other lakes are Lake Davis and Frenchman Lake. From Loggins (2016), Antelope Lake is part of the six lakes study reported by a collaboration of California Audubon chapters. Has the highest reproduction of the six lakes except for 2015 when wind storms damaged nests. Tours have been conducted for viewing the grebe population on this lake. This lake is part of the State Water Project for which statewide water demand has an impact on reservoir levels.

title: Havasu National Wildlife Refuge including Topock Marsh
Havasu National Wildlife Refuge, Topock Marsh
Batiquitos Lagoon
primary_emergent_veg: Cattails; California cord grass (Spartina foliosa); bulrushes; spiny rush; sedges
management_agency: City of Carlsbad, California Department of Fish and Wildlife; Batiquitos Lagoon Foundation (BLF)
region_associations: San Diego County; Southern California; San Marcos Creek; Encinitas Creek
comments: Batiquitos Lagoon is a coastal wetland in the San Diego metropolitan area. It is an Ecological Reservr that includes salt marsh, willow forest, intertidal mudflats, and brackish marsh. Ranching and recreation were previous uses of the area. It is one of the few estuarine coastal wetlands remaining in southern California.

title: Big Lake
management_agency: California Department of Fish and Wildlife; California State Parks
comments: In Shasta County, part of Ahjumawi Lava Springs State Park. Horr Pond is a portion of Big Lake. Horr is the family that donated the land to CA State Parks.

title: Black Butte Lake
region_associations: Eagle Pass Recreation Area; Sacramento Valley
comments: North end of Sacramento Valley. This lake may have high mercury levels.

title: Bridgeport Reservoir
region_associations: Walker River; Topaz Lake; Antelope Valley
comments: Large mountain lake that can be 50 feet deep when full. Most of the marshes have been heavily grazed by cattle. Has had toxic algae warnings.

title: Buena Vista Lagoon
management_agency: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
comments: Freshwater lagoon designated as ecological reserve right on the coast.

title: Butt Valley Lake/Butt Valley Reservoir

comments: Close to Lake Almanor, a major grebe breeding lake.

title: Calaveras Reservoir

comments: Closed to the public.

title: Calero Reservoir

region_associations: Calero County Park; Santa Cruz Mountains; Calera Creek
comments: Calero Reservoir has enough mercury that the fish is unsafe to eat. Supplies water to treatment plants, recharges groundwater, and stores water from Almaden Reservoir.

title: Casitas Reservoir/Lake Casitas
management_agency: U.S. Bureau of Reclamation; Ventura County Watershed Protection District; Casitas Municipal Water District

title: Clear Lake
primary_emergent_veg:
Tule (Typhus sp. and Sciurpus sp.)| tules (Schoenoplectus
spp.)| hardstem bulrush
primary_veg_for_nesting: bulrush (Scirpus sp.)| Tule (Typhus sp. and Sciurpus sp.)| Along shore: tules (Schoenoplectus spp.); smartweed (Persicaria spp.); water primrose (Ludwigia peploides); willows (Salix spp.). In open water: pondweed (Stuckenia spp.)| bulrush; various pondweeds and submerged aquatic plants
management_agency: California Department of Parks and Recreation; U.S. Forest Service; Bureau of Land Management
comments: Clear Lake, in Lake County of northern California, is the oldest lake in North America and one of the largest freshwater lakes of the state. Clear Lake has been particularly impacted by adverse anthropogenic activity such as acid mine drainage and mining activities that leached mercury into the lake, the use of dichlorodiphenyldichloroethane (DDD) to control Clear Lake gnat populations, introduced nonnative fishes, and the destruction of wetland habitats to development. It is highly productive and shallow. Considered the third most important grebe breeding lake in the state, it is impacted by various threats and grebes have had consistently low productivity. See survey data footnotes for more information.

title: Corcoran Irrigation Reservoir
region_associations: Central Joaquin Valley; Tulare Lake Bed
comments: Irrigation reservoir but cannot locate. Coordinates are for the Corcoran Irrigation District office.

title: Crowley Lake/Lake Crowley (Long Valley Lake/Lone Valley Lake)
management_agency: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
comments: Los Angeles Aqueduct System's largest reservoir.

title: Davis Wetlands
comments: Was used to treat wastewater since 1996 until a treatment plant was built in 2018.

title: Eagle Lake
primary_emergent_veg: Tule (Schoenoplectus spp.)| Tule (Typhus sp. and Sciurpus sp.)| bulrush| bulrush (Scirpus sp.)| hard-stemmed bulrush
primary_veg_for_nesting: Tule (Schoenoplectus spp.)| Tule (Typhus sp. and Sciurpus sp.)| bulrush; sago pondweed; bladderwort| bulrush (Scirpus sp.)| hard-stemmed bulrush; common bladderwort; Sago pondweed| hard-stemmed bulrush (Schoenoplectus acutus var. occidentalis); Baltic rush (Juncus balticus)
management_agency: U.S. Forest Service; Bureau of Land Management
region_associations: Lassen National Forest; Great Basin; Cascades; Sierra Nevada
comments: Eagle Lake, in Lassen County, is the second largest lake in California after Clear Lake. It is a natural closed basin lake so water levels vary with inflow. It is situated where the Cascades, Sierra Nevada range, and the Great Basin meet. Recreation has increased in recent years and may cause potential disturbance to waterbirds and other wildlife that use the lake. See footnote from survey data of how important Eagle Lake is to Western and Clark's grebe breeding populations. It is considered the number one breeding lake for grebes in California and a major breeding lake of the intermountain west. There was no nesting from 2012 through 2016. Chicks were observed again in 2017.

title: East Park Reservoir
management_agency: U.S. Bureau of Reclamation; Colusa County Public Works
comments: BOR's smallest and oldest water delivery reservoir in the state.

title: Edwards Air Force Base, Piute Ponds
comments: The largest freshwater marsh in Los Angeles County, water is supplied by effluent from Los Angeles County sewage treatment plant.

title: Finney-Ramer Waterfowl Area
management_agency: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
comments: Finney and Ramer Lakes are part of the Finney-Ramer Unit of Imperial Wildlife Area (7,900 acres total).

title: Funks Reservoir
comments: Not much information on this reservoir.

title: Lake Almanor
primary_emergent_veg: Depends on water levels: Willow (Salix spp.); cattails (Typha spp.); pondweed (Potamogeton spp.)
primary_veg_for_nesting: Depends on water levels: Willow (Salix spp.); cattail (Typha spp.); pondweed (Potamogeton spp.)| in open water ~70 m from shore with pondweeds (P. nodosus; P. crispus; P. pectinatus)
region_associations: Lassen National Forest; Lassen Volcanic National Park; Plumas National Forest; Lake Almanor Basin
comments: Lake Almanor is one of the largest reservoirs in California and a popular lake for fishing and recreation. It was constructed by Pacific Gas and Electric (PG&E) to generate hydropower. There is a diversity of wildlife habitat in the surrounding region as Lassen National Forest, Lassen Volcanic National Park, and Plumas National Forest are adjacent to the lake. See survey data footnote for more information. Kyle et al. (2015) states that Lake Almanor is the 4th most important grebe breeding lake in CA. Ivey (2004) states this lake has 12.0% of the nests and represents 5.4% of the grebes of the Intermountain West (Ivey and Herziger in prep.). Nearly total failure of the colonies due to low water levels in 2002. Biggest threat is water level drawdown partially due to generating power.

title: Lake Berryessa
management_agency: U.S. Bureau of Reclamation; Solano County Water Agency/Solano Irrigation District
lake_use: irrigation; water supply; flood control; recreation
region_associations: Napa Valley; Lake Berryessa Recreation Area
comments: One of the largest lakes of Napa Valley and California.

title: Lake Cachuma/Cachuma Reservoir
management_agency: U.S. Bureau of Reclamation; Cachuma Operation and Maintenance Board
region_associations: Santa Barbara; South Coast; Santa Ynez River
comments: A large seacoast reservoir that captures water that would otherwise flow to sea.

title: Lake Davis
motorboat_restriction_notes: no water skiing nor jet skiing
management_agency: U.S. Forest Service; California Department of Fish and Wildlife
region_associations: Plumas National Forest; Lake Davis Recreation Area; Upper River Feather Lakes
comments: Deepest part of lake is 108 feet. It has the largest biomass of any still water lake in California. Lake was treated with Rotenone in 2007 to rid it of invasive northern pike. It is vulnerable to wind storms.

title: Lake Earl and Lake Talawa
management_agency: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
region_associations: Lake Earl Wildlife Area; Lake Tolowa; Pacific Coast; Del Norte Coast; Tolowa Dunes State Park
comments: Coastal lagoon connected to Lake Tolowa via a channel called the Narrows. Part of Lake Earl Wildlife Area, Lake Earl is the largest lake in Del Norte County. Considered ornithologically important and is the largest coastal lagoon south of Alaska.

title: Lake Earl
surface_area_km2: 19.5 at high water level, 8.9 when open to ocean
primary_emergent_veg: hardstem bulrush (Scirpus acutus); Three Square Bulrush (Scirpus americanus)
management_agency: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
region_associations: Lake Earl Wildlife Area; Lake Tolowa; Pacific Coast; Del Norte Coast; Tolowa Dunes State Park
comments: Coastal lagoon connected to Lake Tolowa via a channel called the Narrows. Part of Lake Earl Wildlife Area, it is the largest lake in Del Norte County. Considered ornithologically important and is the largest coastal lagoon south of Alaska.

title: Lake Evans and Lake Webb and Buena Vista Lake (historical), Buena Vista Aquatic Recreation Area
comments: Adjacent to Lake Webb, this lake is Kern County that was drained for agriculture (Ivey 2004). There is a historic Buena Vista Lake about 6 miles south of this location but Robison et. al (2008) refers to the Buena Vista Aquatic Recreation Area and the Buena Vista Lake mentioned in Ivey as the same location. Grouped them together.

title: Lake Hennessey
region_associations: Napa Valley; Lake Hennessey Recreation Area
comments: Water levels considered lower than historical levels.

title: Lake Henshaw
comments: Supplies 30% of Vista Irrigation District's water.

title: Lake Hodges/Hodges Reservoir
management_agency: City of San Diego Public Utilities Department| San Diego Water Authority; San Diego Gas and Electric; City of San Diego Public Utilities Department
region_associations: San Dieguito River watershed; San Dieguita Water District; Santa Fe Irrigation District; City of San Diego; Olivenhain Reservoir; San Pasqual Valley
comments: Provides water for San Dieguita Water District, Santa Fe Irrigation District, and City of San Diego. It is connected to and downstream from Olivenhain Reservoir.

title: Lake Isabella
management_agency: Kern County Parks and Recreation, U.S. Forest Service, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers
region_associations: Kern River, Sequoia National Forest, Central Valley, Bakersfield
comments: Open water can experience gusts up to 60 mph.

title: Lake Mendocino
management_agency: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers; Sonoma Water
lake_use: flood control; hydroelectricity; water supply; irrigation
comments: Dual-purpose reservoir that is used for flood control and provides water supply.

title: Lake Merced
motorboat_restriction_notes: No gas-powered in the North Merced only
management_agency: San Francisco Recreation and Parks Department; San Francisco Public Utilities Commission
comments: Spring fed dual lake system that is larger than other San Francisco area lakes. In the 1980s, surrounding golf courses drew groundwater for irrigation, drawing down water levels. In 1994, lake levels reached record low of 14 feet in depth. Lake level top off level is 30 feet.

title: Lake San Antonio
management_agency: Monterey County Water Resources Agency; Monterey County Department of Public Works, Facilities, & Parks
comments: The reservoir's main use is for groundwater recharge and flood control. Part of Lake San Antonio Recreation Area.

title: Lake Shastina
management_agency: California State Water Resources Control Board (CEDEN)
comments: Provides irrigation water for the Shasta Valley.

title: Lake Skinner/Skinner Reservoir
management_agency: Riverside County Regional Park and Open-Space District; Metropolitan Water District
comments: Water is brought in from the Rocky Mountains and Northern California, where it is more plentiful, into this and other reservoirs in Southern California.  Part of Lake Skinner Recreation Area.

title: Lake Success
lake_use: flood control; water supply; hydroelectricity; recreation
region_associations: Tule River; Central Valley; Sacramento; Sierra Nevada foothills
comments: Multipurpose reservoir is also managed for wildlife habitat.

title: Los Banos Reservoir/Los Banos Creek Reservoir
management_agency: US Bureau of Reclamation; California Department of Water Resources; California Department of Parks and Recreation; California Department of Fish and Wildlife
comments: Popular for fishing.

title: Loveland Reservoir
region_associations: Sweetwater River; San Diego County; Southern California
comments: This reservoir supplies water to Chula Vista and Bonita.

title: Lower Klamath Lake, Lower Klamath National Wildlife Refuge
region_associations: Lower Klamath Basin; Klamath Basin National Wildlife Refuge Complex; Klamath River
comments: Combined records for Lower Klamath Lake and just Lower Klamath NWR because the lake comprises a big part of the refuge and assuming these records are regarding same approximate locations. At California-Oregon border, this lake became dry and is facing a water crisis at what is a major migratory bird stopover. It also has major water quality issues.

title: Lower Klamath private area, includes Chalk Banks/The Honker Hunt Clubs, Indian Tom Lake and area south of, Alkali Lakes, and Marsh Island Ranch
comments: Lower Klamath private area includes Chalk Banks/The Honker Hunt Clubs, Indian Tom Lake, area south of Indian Tom, Alkali Lakes, and Marsh Island Ranch. These coordinates are for Indian Tom Lake because that is the only searchable location on Google Earth.

title: Lower Otay Reservoir/Lower Otay Lake
management_agency: San Diego Public Utilities Department; City of San Diego Water Department
comments: Supplies water for San Diego area. Houses the United States Olympic Training Center for rowing.

title: Modoc National Wildlife Refuge
comments: Coordinates are for Goose Pond of the refuge though no specific location was named. East of the Klamath Basin on the western edge of the Great Basin.

title: Mono Basin
management_agency: Los Angeles Department of Water and Power (LADWP); U.S. Forest Service; Bureau of Land Management; Mono County
comments: Mono Lake was the location Ivey cites but D. Shuford believes it is Mono Basin in general because Mono Lake is historically and currently hypersaline and without fish nor vegetation. Coordinates are for Mono Basin which is adjacent to Mono Lake, one of the oldest lakes of North America. Water is diverted from Mono Lake tributaries in the basin via the Los Angeles Water Aqueduct system for use in the Los Angeles metropolitan area. The basin is a large area that includes both natural lakes and reservoirs.

title: Mountain Meadows Reservoir (Walker Lake)
management_agency: Pacific Gas & Electric Company; Feather River Land Trust; California Department of Fish and Wildlife; Mountain Meadows Conservancy
comments: Mountain Meadows Reservoir is a conservation easement that allows public access. The reservoir went dry in 2015 due to drought and structural problems and CA Department of Fish and Wildlife worked to restore the fishery. Shallow lake where deepest part is 16 feet.

title: Northern California
comments: General description of a large region. This is a summary of Northern California lakes (Tule Lake NWR, Lake Earl, Eagle Lake, Mountain Meadows Reservoir, Lake Almanor, Thermalito Afterbay, East Park Reservoir, Clear Lake, and Mendota Wildlife Area).

title: Great Basin (CA, NV, UT, OR, WY)
management_agency: U.S. Bureau of Land Management (management of most of the land in the basin)
comments: A modelling research article, not a survey. The Great Basin is a large arid region that includes smaller basins, such as the Great Salt Lake and the Klamath Basin. Precipitation does not flow out towards the ocean but rather evaporates or sinks into groundwater and interior waterbodies that tend to be saline. The Great Basin is one of the dryest regions of the U.S. and spans across the states of Nevada, Utah, and parts of Wyoming, Oregon, Idaho, and California. Temperate desert, sagebrush landscapes, saline lakes, and mountainous terrain support a diversity of wildlife. The Great Basin faces water resource challenges like other arid regions. High water demand, drought, and climate change have resulted in drastically low water levels in waterbodies throughout the region. Various public-private partnership alliances and resolutions have been proposed to address these ongoing resource issues.

title: O'Neill Forebay
management_agency: California Department of Fish and Wildlife; U.S. Bureau of Reclamation
region_associations: Central Valley Project; San Luis Joint Use Project; O'Neill Forebay Wildlife Area

title: O'Neill Lake/Lake O'Neill, Camp Pendleton
management_agency: U.S. Marine Corps; U.S. Bureau of Reclamation
region_associations: Lake O'Neill Recreational Park; Camp Pendleton; Santa Margarita River
comments: In San Diego County, O'Neill Lake is different from O'Neill Forebay. Western and Clark's grebes were mostly wintering species in San Diego County lakes and reservoirs until the 1950s, when they started to breed there. Unitt (2004) proposes that building dams, filling reservoirs, and stocking them with fish encouraged grebes to breed in those inland waters in increasing numbers.

title: Klamath Basin
comments: An estimated total of Klamath Basin with no specific location. This is a very large region so no coordinates provided nor entered here. Klamath Basin is an important region for grebe breeding and the adult numbers represent 5% of Clark's grebes and 15% to 30% of Western grebes of their North American population at the time. The Central Subregion had 70% to 80% of the Western and Clark's grebes surveyed in 2003 and 2004. This region includes the Upper Klamath Lake area, Sprague River Valley, Klamath River, Spring Lake area, Yonna Valley area, and Gerben/Willow Valley area.

title: Palmdale Lake
management_agency: Palmdale Fin and Feather Club (private); Palmdale Water District
region_associations: Los Angeles; California State Water Project
comments: Palmdale Fin and Feather Club leases the lake from the Palmdale Water District.

title: Perris Reservoir (Lake Perris)
region_associations: Lake Perris Recreation Area; California State Water Project
comments: Perris Reservoir is the most southern reservoir of the California State Water Project.

title: Ramer Lake
management_agency: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
region_associations: Imperial Wildlife Area, Salton Sea; Finney Lake
comments: In the Salton Sea area, this lake is part of Imperial Wildlife Area near Finney Lake and is closed.

title: Sacramento National Wildlife Refuge
comments: No specific location provided at this refuge. Coordinates are for Pool 2, the largest waterbody in the refuge. This refuge is part of a complex of refuges in the Central Valley and the last known remnant of a large Central Valley grebe population. A few grebes attempt to nest here every year. The lake was drained and refilled in March 1976. The lake was drained and refilled in March 1976. Current drought conditions.

title: Salton Sea, Sonny Bono Salton Sea National Wildlife Refuge
management_agency: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service; California Department of Fish and Wildlife; Salton Sea Authority
region_associations: Sonny Bono Salton Sea NWR; Salton Sea State Recreation Area; Coachella Valley; Imperial Irrigation District; Historic Colorado River Delta
comments: The largest lake in California, the Salton Sea is a terminal lake that is 50% saltier than the sea. While functioning as a sump for agriculture runoff, it has is one of the largest most biodiverses avian communities in the southwest. It is threatened by increasing salinity and water quality issues.

title: San Dieguito Reservoir
management_agency: Santa Fe Irrigation District (SFID); San Dieguito Water District (SDWD)
region_associations: Lake Hodges; San Dieguito Watershed Management Area; San Dieguito River
comments: This terminal reservoir stores water from Lake Hodges and provides emergency water to the Santa Fe Irrigation District (SFID) and the San Dieguito Water District (SDWD). It also serves as a flood control facility and is fenced off and closed to public access.

title: San Jacinto Lake (Mystic Lake)
management_agency: Lakeview Investment Company (private); U.S. Army Corps of Engineers
comments: Construction of levees diverted water away from this lake and it remains either dry or ephemeral. This lake along with the wetland complex of the valley is considered a significant inland wetland of California. Was dry for 15 years until rain filled it with water again in 2019.

title: San Joaquin Marsh Wildlife Sanctuary
comments: The San Joaquin Marsh Wildlife Sanctuary are a complex of constructed wetlands used to hold urban runoff water for Irvine River Water District's Natural Water Treatment System.

title: San Luis National Wildlife Refuge
region_associations: San Luis Refuge Complex; Bear Creek; Salt Slough; San Joaquin River floodplain; Central California
comments: One the last remaining historic wetlands in the Pacific Flyway in central California. No specific location named in the refuge so coordinates are of a large waterbody within the refuge.

title: Shasta Valley WA
management_agency: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
comments: No specific location given for this WA so coordinates are for Trout Lake. Shasta Valley Wildlife Area has lack of water currently and is shut down.

title: South Wilbur Flood Area
comments: Cannot locate this site in Ivey (2004) but it is in Kings County.

title: Southern California summary of Cachuma Reservoir, Casitas Reservoir, Skinner Reservoir, Lake Hodges, and Lower Otay
comments: This is a Southern California summary of Cachuma Reservoir, Casitas Reservoir, Skinner Reservoir, Lake Hodges, and Lower Otay, not about an individual lake.

title: Stockton
comments: Uncertain location in Stockton. Ivey 2004 refers to Stockton as "before the Delta was reclaimed." Coordinates for "The Delta" area of Stockton, which is near McLeod Lake.

title: Stony Gorge Reservoir
comments: This reservoir is a warm water fishery. The California Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment issued a fish advisory for this reservoir.

title: Sutter Basin
management_agency: Sutter Mutual Water Company (SMWC); Bureau of Reclamation; Basin Irrigation and Drainage Authority
region_associations: Sacramento Valley; Feather River; Sacramento River
comments: A large basin composed of a complex of levees and channels bound by the Feather and Sacramento Rivers.

title: Sweetwater Reservoir/Sweetwater Lake
comments: Provides water to National City, Bonita, and parts of Chula Vista.

title: The 6 Lakes (Clear, Eagle, Almanor, Thermalito, Davis and Antelope)
region_associations: Clear Lake; Eagle Lake; Almanor Lake; Thermalito Afterbay; Lake Davis; Antelope Lake
comments: This is a summary of the 6 Lakes (Clear, Eagle, Almanor, Thermalito, Davis and Antelope).

title: Thermalito Afterbay
management_agency: California Department of Fish and Wildlife; California Department of Water Resources
region_associations: Oroville Dam Complex; Lake Oroville; Oroville Wildlife Area; Feather River; Thermalito Forebay
comments: Part of Oroville Dam Complex, 5th most important grebe breeding lake in CA and they have nested there for at least 20 years. No consistent surveys until Dept of Water Resources started in 2004 and now collaborates with Altacal Audubon and Audubon's Grebe Conservation Project. Though number of threats named in this report, human disturbance from waterskiing and water level fluctuation are the main threats behind nest abandonment and low breeding success. Water flows through the Oroville-Thermalito Complex and into the Thermalito Forebay then into Thermalito Afterbay to be used to generate electricity. Altacal Audubon does extensive education and outreach on grebes of the lake.

title: Tinemaha Reservoir
management_agency: California Department of Water Resources; City of Los Angeles Department of Water and Power
region_associations: Owens Valley; Los Angeles Aqueduct System; base of Eastern Sierra Nevadas
comments: One of the reservoirs that supplies water to Los Angeles via the Los Angeles Aqueduct System.

title: Topaz Lake
management_agency: Mono County (CA); Douglas County (NV); Douglas County Parks and Recreation (NV)
region_associations: Topaz Lake County Park; Topaz Lake Recreation Area; Eastern Sierra; Antelope Valley
comments: Part of Topaz Lake County Park and Topaz Lake Recreation Area, this is a man-made lake on the CA and NV border.

title: Tulare Lake (historic)
management_agency: California Department of Fish and Wildlife; U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
comments: Was a large complex of wetlands until irrigation upstream cut off water sources to the lake, leaving it dry by 1899. Since then, the lakebed captures water from runoff, groundwater, and State Water Project and Central Valley Project water deliveries. Due to recent rains, water has flooded the area and filled the lake.

title: Tule Lake, Tule Lake National Wildlife Refuge
management_agency: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service; Bureau of Reclamation; Tulelake Irrigation District
region_associations: Tule Lake Basin; Klamath Basin; Great Basin; Lower Klamath National Wildlife Refuge; Upper Klamath National Wildlife Refuge
comments: Tule Lake and Tule Lake NWR (in general without specific location in the refuge) data compiled together because Tule Lake comprises most of the refuge. Finley (1907) observed large numbers of breeding grebes at Tule Lake and noted as colony site but hunters decimated this population. No year in this report but probably late 1800s or early 1900s. Ivey (2004) refers to Tule Lake as the second highest number of grebes of the selected sites at 17.3%, and 7.8% of the breeding grebe population of the Intermountain West (Ivey and Herziger in prep.). In summer of 2020, Ducks Unlimited partnered with various managing agencies to drawdown water from Sump 1B to expose mudflats for wetland vegetation seed germination.. These efforts were taken in hopes of providing nesting habitat for grebes. Tule Lake is considered highly productive and an important stopover site for migratory birds on the Pacific Flyway.

title: Whitewater River Estuary
management_agency: Wildlands Conservancy; Bureau of Land Management
comments: Uncertain where this estuary is within Riverside County so these coordinates are for the river in general.

title: Woodward Reservoir
comments: No water contact warnings issued.

title: Adams Lake
comments: The Adams Lake in Alamosa County.

title: Arkansas River Valley and San Luis Valley reservoirs
comments: One of the major river basins of Colorado with great irrigation demand. Arkansas River Valley has a very high municipal and commercial water use in Colorado. The San Luis Valley of the Rio Grande River area is economically depressed.

title: Boyd Lake
